case_studies.name: BrainVR

description.brief: A traditional Japanese lamp that responds gesturally to weather phenomena.
description.extensive: A traditional Japanese lamp that responds gesturally to weather phenomena using an integrated micro controller + Connectivity to remote weather stations. The lamp seeks to explore our relationship with dynamic data, for this instance weather. How much do we really need to know? When is a qualitative understanding of data sufficient? The lamp is also a sort of commentary on the current state of culture in Japan. It is no coincidence that the lamp resembles a tower crane. The lamp bridges the gap between traditional Japanese culture and Japan as a world-leading technological hub. The Lamp is a collaboration between Massart’s graphic design program and MIT’s Architectural Computation department. The following pages detail the CAD models and a bit of the building process for the first of the 3 proposed lamps, this is the smallest desk lamp. Further on there is a glimpse into the program written to aggregate weather sources as well as a web-interface designed to program + control the lamp.
description.long_1: A traditional Japanese lamp that responds gesturally to weather phenomena using an integrated micro controller + Connectivity to remote weather stations. The lamp seeks to explore our relationship with dynamic data, for this instance weather. How much do we really need to know? When is a qualitative understanding of data sufficient? The lamp is also a sort of commentary on the current state of culture in Japan.

bios_text.title:
Designer | Researcher
Creative Coder
bios_text.description_pull: Design at the intersection of people and technology, weaving lessons from natural systems into creative solutions and computational models.
bios_text.description_short: Hello, I am an interaction designer and researcher currently at Eyewire. Driven by a passion for innovation and cross disciplinary collaboration, I see the world through the lens of design. My work focuses on the intersection of people and technology, weaving lessons from natural systems into creative solutions, delightful interactions, and computational models.
bios_text.description_long:
Having split my undergraduate years between MassArt and MIT Media Lab, I occupy the cross-disciplinary space between the physical and the digital, data and expression; a radical atom if you will. I loves setting beautiful typography, the careful design of information, generative physics, and crafting delightful interactive narrative experiences across devices and platforms.

My visualizations have been featured at TED, Tribeca Film Festival, and in Times Square NYC. My renderings have appeared in Wired magazine, the New York Times, and Nature scientific journal.

When not designing, I can be found in search of the perfect breeze, windsurfing or sailing off the coast of Cape Cod.

feature.caption: See the brain in new dimensions.
Play a game to map the brain.
What if you could see ideas worth spreading?
A videogame that recruits players to map the brain.
How the brain's wiring makes you, you.
Space–time wiring specificity supports direction selectivity in the retina.
Virtual reality is here, and brands of all stripes are embracing the tech.
Eyewire takes over Times Square for an entire month
Explore the brain in new dimensions.

feature.project: A Game to Map the Brain
feature.caption: Introducing a game to map the brain.
VR is here and with it, scientific visualizations.
70,000 gamers are playing a game to map the brain.

contact.shout_out: Interested in working together or simply meeting up?
contact.shout_out_sub: I love sharing adventures, discovering new design, and nerding out on emerging technology—especially VR + AI.
